title: How to manual copy mp4 file?
content: I have tried using some popular editors like: sublime text, notepad++ to open mp4 file and after copy content of it. After copy, I added the mp4 extension to the newly copied file. As a result, the new mp4 file cannot be opened even though it has the same content as the old file, so what did I miss when copying it, a header for example?

comments.text: Bad idea. Editors are text editor. MP4 are binary files. Opening and saving binary file in a text editor very often ends up in changes to the content because of charset de-/encoding. Why don't you simply copy the file? If you want to manually edit a file use a hex editor.
maybe the new file does not have the mp4 extension

The problem is that I have an external ssd drive, but when I copy data from there, I check its content as an old file, but when I open it, it is damaged, it is similar to the above case when I need to copy the content with the editor.
Then may be the files have been downloaded e.g. via FTP in text mode (instead of binary mode).

answers_data.content:
It is unclear what you are trying to achieve. If you want to copy mp4 or any binary non-printable content as if it was a text file then the closest option is to open the file using a hex editor (ex. HxD for Windows), instead of a text editor like Notepad++.
This will not help if the file is damaged in any way.
